Of course, deserted places are also handy for horror film directors in that it's more realistic that you will have no phone coverage there either.

No matter what kind of house it is, the basement is a scary place in horror films. That's usually where something is hiding or where the bad crazy person has hidden their tools. Basements are always dark and often damp. You can only reach them by a narrow set of stairs. And basements are always frightening, even when there isn't anything down there.

Gary Collins, an off-duty policeman, was watching the London trouble on TV. He immediately recognised several people and cut his holiday short to help with naming people. He ended up spending six months going through the CCTV film and managed to point out 190 people, many from their eyes alone. His help was of very great importance in the investigation. Even with 200,000 hours of film, face-matching software managed to find just one person.

Personally, I think it's interesting to consider how we'll speed up our development as a group by improving our bodies. Imagine if you could put a computer inside our brain! Soon we'll be able to do just that and make better our number ability, sight and sound understanding and our memory, and this idea is only going to become more and more normal.

It was a fascinating talk and the speaker was really right about some points. Take parental influence, for example. How can we expect teenagers not to text while doing homework when they see their parents posting on social media while cooking dinner or waiting at a red traffic light? She also made a good point about people who want to be in two or more places at the same time. So they switch back and forth between their real conversations and online conversations. I see this all the time with my teenage daughter and her friends. They make plans to meet and then sit together silently while each one has a different conversation online.

As for news stories that make us think the world is an increasingly violent place, there is reason for some hope too. Between the end of World War II and 1990, there were 30 wars that killed more than 100,000 people. Today there are still civil wars, but countries are mostly living together more calmly than in the past. However, terrorism has shot up in the last few years and, since World War II, wars have killed many more civilians than soldiers. Even for civilians, the numbers are not all bad. Although deaths are nine times more likely to be a result of violent crime than political conflict, the global murder rate fell slightly, from 8 per 100,000 people in 2000 to about 5.3 in 2015.

Wasfia has dedicated her life to supporting human rights and has seen numerous international aid programs in her home country to educate and train women and girls. But once too often they have been left with nothing when such programs have stopped running. Wasfia saw that Bangladesh needed to stand up for itself. So she brought together two of her passions, mountaineering and human rights, in order to try and change attitudes towards women in her country. She at first took up climbing while working on aid efforts in Tibet and Nepal. In a coastal, primarily flat country like Bangladesh, most people have never set eyes on a mountain. Her effort seems to be doing the trick as other men and women in her country are sitting up and taking notice along with the rest of the world.

Most people believe that developing countries are in a terrible situation: They suffer from extreme poverty, are ruled by dictators, and have little hope for real change. But surprisingly, this is far from the truth. The reality is, however, that a big change is happening. In the last 20 years, more than 700 million people have increased their income and left poverty behind. Also, six million fewer children die from diseases each year, millions more girls go to school, and millions of people have access to clean water.

Many managers try to make feedback more positive by putting negative comments between two positive ones. However, when feedback becomes this kind of routine, employees may start to see positive feedback as just a way to make the negative parts seem better. This makes the positive feedback less valuable. Instead, positive feedback should not just be used to soften negative comments. It should be given in a way that strengthens and encourages good performance.

I'm a member of the group called Stop Killer Robots. Forget the movie image of a scary killer robot stepping on human heads, and think about what is happening now: military machines like flying robots, guns fixed in one place, and guard robots are already being used to kill with very little control from people. The next step will be 'murderbots' that act on their own, follow orders, and in the end decide by themselves who to kill. To me, it is clear this would be completely wrong and dangerous for all people. We need to be very careful about what we ask machines to do.

In general, more people are studying English than the other languages combined and English is spoken in the highest number of countries. However, Chinese has by far the greatest number of native speakers. There seems to be little connection between how many native speakers a language has and the number of people studying it. However, there is a stronger link between the number of learners and how many countries have speakers.

Your manager stops you and says she needs to have a word about your performance in the recent work. You worry about it all weekend, wondering what you might have done wrong. When you step into her office on Monday morning she begins by saying good things about the good work you've done on the recent work, and you wonder if this is the required praise that starts off the typical 'comments sandwich'. You know how the comments sandwich goes: say something nice, say what you really want to say, say something nice again.

Even though Born in the USA is a fast rock album that makes you want to tap your feet, its lyrics carry a deep emotional feeling. Behind the catchy rock melodies that power these classic songs, there are stories about the difficult parts of the American Dream. Many songs show the struggles of ordinary people who work hard. They feel bitter and angry when life doesn't give them wealth or fame. For example, the song Glory Days is about people in a small town who remember their youth, when they had many opportunities. Another song, Downbound Train, tells the story of a young man whose life is ruined when he loses his job. It's easy to imagine that the artist writes about real people he knew and the life he might have had if he hadn't become a famous star. The album clearly shows The Boss's special and great talent.

Lewis wants to see the number of protected areas in the world's oceans increase from 3 percent to 10 percent. This would help fix the damage caused by human activities like too much fishing, pollution, and trash. On his trips, Lewis has seen this damage to the environment up close. He has swum over coral reefs that turned white because the water got too warm. He also saw empty underwater areas in the shallow waters of the Red Sea, which had no life and were covered in plastic. Pugh believes that nature can recover if we give it enough space, but time is running out. If we don't start taking care of our oceans, we might soon have a problem we can't fix.

Best-selling author Terrie Sharp knows how to tell a good story or two, having twice won the Olive Crime Writer Award. Born in the housing area in Glasgow, which had the highest crime rate, she learned to keep quiet and stay out of trouble. She also learned how to open car doors with a knife. Luckily, she only used her knowledge to write her novels. She's not so quiet these days, appearing on popular daily shows like Police Today and at writing talks throughout the UK.

Some people worry that things are getting worse every day. They might think progress is not possible. But in his book, Enlightenment Now, Steven Pinker looks at how humans have made progress. He finds good news. He says that we now live longer, healthier, freer, and happier lives. Pinker says the real problem is that people are attacking important ideas like reason and science. These ideas come from the Enlightenment. When people who speak in public try to make others feel divided, hopeless, or not trusting, then important systems can be badly hurt. These important systems include democracy and countries working together.

In older horror films, when main characters were in great fear, it was difficult or impossible for them to call for help or call the police. Mobile phones have made that situation a bit less realistic now. What's the solution to maintain excitement? No phone coverage! If you're a hero in a horror film, it's almost certain that at a key moment, just when you absolutely need to call for help, you will not have any coverage at all. Or your phone battery will die just as you are making the call. Or both.

In the 1950s, Central American commercial banana growers were facing the death of their most money-making product, the Gros Michel banana, called Big Mike. And now it's happening again to Big Mike's successor – the Cavendish. With its easily moved, thick-skinned and sweet-tasting fruit, the Gros Michel banana plant was the main plant on the plantations of Central America. United Fruit, the main grower and seller to other countries in South America at the time, made its bananas in very large numbers in the most efficient way possible. It cloned shoots from the stems of plants instead of raising plants from seeds, and cultivated them in fields where plants were very close together.

Spider poison is present in most types and serves the purpose of stunning or killing the animals they catch rather than attacking humans. In fact, only 25 of the recorded spider types produce poison which can actually harm humans, and although spider bites can be painful, they are rarely deadly. Australia's notorious Sydney funnel-web spider has not produced any fatalities since anti-poison was developed in 1981. However, take care not to stroke furry spiders like tarantulas up the wrong way. When they feel in danger, they defend themselves by shooting out a cloud of itchy hairs. These itchy hairs then stick into the skin or eyes of the attacker.

This horror film cliché was especially popular with horror films of the late 20th century. It starts with a group of teenagers all enjoying themselves, and it ends with everyone dead except one girl. At the beginning the girl is usually innocent, shy and not particularly strong. By the end, she has become the strongest and most capable person in the world. The last girl almost always wins in the end.

If we want to know where our ability for complex language comes from, we need to look at how our brains are different from those of other animals. This is about more than just brain size. It's important to understand what else our brains can do, and when and why they developed in this way. But we have very few physical clues about this. Things left behind by our ancestors don't tell us what kind of language they could speak. However, one thing we *can* see in the remains of early humans is how their mouth, throat, and tongue developed. Around 100,000 years ago, people developed the ability to make complex sounds. Before that time, scientists who study evolution can only guess if early humans used simpler sounds to communicate, or not.

It is society, not nature, that tells us girls should favour arts and humanities and leave maths and physics to the boys. Coupled with this is the lack of positive female role models young people see doing science-connected jobs. Cartoons and stories often show the crazy scientist, very smart creator, or brave astronaut as a man. Furthermore, there is an unfortunate belief that scientists are not cool, have poor social skills or that their work is lonely and separate from the rest of the world. These are false fixed ideas shown by news and TV, but they may mean girls do not feel close to scientists, and see science as an unattractive career path. If girls saw more positive female role models in science it would give them more confidence and a greater sense of belonging in those subjects.

The Scallion is printed weekly and distributed free in university buildings, with a readership of approximately 10,000 students. It is written and produced entirely by students. The survey shows that the newspaper is highly valued by university students and staff for entertainment, cultural improvement and work experience. The cost of printing newspapers is significant. Furthermore, some students cannot easily get the paper, since the only way to obtain a copy is to physically go to university. An additional environmental issue is that a large number of copies end up as trash on campus.

At Girox Foods, we are experiencing an annual rate of workers leaving at about 12 per cent. Although this might not seem high at first glance, the industry standard is seven per cent. The principal objective of this report is to look into the causes of worker involvement within the firm. Based on those, it will offer suggestions to improve workers' experience at work and increase how long workers stay.

So much of what the speaker said rang true. I honestly believe there's a danger that the more connected we are, the more alone we feel. I don't think this is such an issue for my generation who've lived without technology for so long. We know how to be alone and, more importantly, we know that it's OK to be alone. But people under 20 are very different. They're so busy communicating that they never experience the feeling of being alone. They run the chance of not finding out how to enjoy their own company. In addition, they are practicing conversation through messages that can be changed and fixed. But they are not learning real conversation with someone face-to-face and in real time.

Don't always follow positive feedback with negative feedback. If positive and negative feedback always seem to come together, the positive feedback might lose its value and be ignored. Make sure there are times when positive feedback is given just for being positive, and try not to offer any constructive criticism then.
